transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: On this Fat Tuesday, we're checking in with the Louisiana family we first met in 2005, shortly after Hurricane Katrina.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: I just got home now. How you doing, man? Donald Bordelon.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: I'm Steve.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: How you doing? I'm Colleen.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: How high did the water get in here?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: In here? How high can you see? That's how high it went, buddy.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Donald and Colleen Bordelon rode out Katrina in that flooded home. We've listened over the years as they slowly started to rebuild. These days, he's still working in a shipyard. She took a job at a gas station on the main street in St. Bernard Parish. Traffic there is still light, and their neighborhood is still mostly empty. But the Bordelons' mood has not changed. Mr. and Mrs. Bordelon?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Hello, Steve. It's a beautiful Monday Gras, man.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Monday Gras?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Monday Gras.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: We're talking on the day before Fat Tuesday, so that's Monday Gras. Okay. Is there a festive feeling at Mardi Gras time here?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Oh, yeah. People love Mardi Gras, man. Mardi Gras is a terrific time. Matter of fact, they only had one parade down in St. Bernard Parish.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: So is one parade in St. Bernard Parish next to New Orleans, is that a large number of parades, a low number of parades? Where is that on the scale?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: It's a low number. We used to have maybe three, four, five parades, but now we just have - well, you don't have the people. The economy -the economy's not like it was before, you know?

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Did you guys make it to the one parade?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: He didn't. I didn't. He had to work. I was working a long weekend.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Colleen Bordelon, you made it out?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Oh, yeah, I made it. It was nice. But the best parade will be like March the 8th. We're having our Irish-Italian parade here. And they throw cabbage and potatoes and carrots.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: You could go away from the parade with a salad?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Oh, yes. And they'll throw little wooden nickels that you can redeem for like, pickle meat, which you put in the cabbage, you know, to cook the cabbage.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: I want to ask about a couple of other things, and I'll let you go. And I regret to bring up this piece of information, but people may want to know. Mr. Bordelon, a couple of years ago we met - we met your father on one of our visits to New Orleans, and I was very sorry to hear that he has passed away.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yeah, he has. The holidays aren't the same. Big loss to us. A real big loss.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: I remember a white-haired gentleman who was incredibly energetic. In fact, he hardly had time to talk with us because he was busy repairing something in your house.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: That's the way he was, you know? That's what kind of got him in, buddy, Hurricane Katrina, you know? Once he finished his house, he just kind of retired to his chair and never did a whole lot of things after that.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Now, this house that you're in, this was his house.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yes, sir.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: That flooded when you were a boy, and he built it again.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yup.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: And he helped you build it again one more time.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yup, sure have.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Is he part of the reason you stayed in that house all these years and even through the trouble of the last few years?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yeah. Well, he was family-oriented. He liked his family close.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: May I ask one more question about your father, Mr. Bordelon?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Sure.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Funerals in New Orleans are famous for being occasions to celebrate someone as much as to mourn them. What was his funeral like?

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: It was beautiful. It really was. It was a beautiful funeral. Everybody come to the house. We just talked about things he did. We cooked shrimp, and we cooked crabs, and we had a party. We had a big party.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Well, when we hear about Mardi Gras celebrations, we're going to think about you folks remembering and celebrating your father.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: Yeah. Thank you very much.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: Donald and Colleen Bordelon, it's always great to talk with you.

transcript.speaker: Mr. Donald Bordelon
transcript.text: You, too. Appreciate y'all calling, you know? Keeping us in your thoughts.

transcript.speaker: Steve Inskeep
transcript.text: This is NPR News.
